facts.text: Appellant is a thika tenant in respect of a portion of the premises No. 28, R. G. Kar Road in Calcutta.
In Suit No. 46 of 1948, a decree for ejectment was passed against the appellant and in favour of the respondent on March 16, 1949.
Appellant preferred appeal before District Court and second appeal before Calcutta High Court; both failed and decree confirmed.
On May 22, 1953, respondent filed execution case before First Additional Court, Sealdah (Title Execution Case No. 34 of 1953) claiming delivery of possession.
Appellant filed Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 96 of 1953 under s.47 CPC raising objections to execution; dismissed by executing court on February 2, 1954.
Miscellaneous appeal before District Judge, 24-Parganas (Misc. Appeal No. 87 of 1954) dismissed on July 29, 1954.
Second miscellaneous appeal before Calcutta High Court (Appellate Order No. 134 of 1954) affirming lower orders, judgment dated March 29, 1955.
Appellant applied for leave under Letters Patent; rejected by Mr. Justice Renupada Mukherjee.
Appellant filed petition for special leave on May 10, 1955; granted on May 18, 1955.
Courts below ordered appellant to vacate premises before end of Jaistha 1362 B.S. (15th June, 1955), failing which execution to proceed.
Decree falls under s.5(2) of Ordinance XV of 1952 (passed between commencement of Act II of 1949 and Ordinance).

legal_issues.text: Whether, under s.5(1) of the Calcutta Thika Tenancy Act, 1949 as amended by Calcutta Thika Tenancy Amendment Act, 1953, execution proceedings against thika tenant can be entertained only by the Controller and not by civil courts.

petitioner_arguments.text: Civil courts lack competence to entertain decree-holder's execution application; proceeds on misconstruction of s.5(1); execution only by Controller.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.5(1) Calcutta Thika Tenancy Act, 1949 as amended; welfare legislation to be beneficently construed per Heydon's case

petitioner_arguments.text: Scheme of Act and amendments affords full protection to thika tenants; ss.5,28,29 require scrutiny of ejectment claims in light of s.3 grounds even for existing decrees.
Deletion of words 'subject to s.28' in s.5(1) indicates Controller has jurisdiction over decrees already passed.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.5(1) as amended by Act VI of 1953

respondent_arguments.text: Civil courts can and ought to entertain decree-holder's execution application.

court_reasoning.text: History of legislation: Ordinance XI/1948 stayed executions; Act II/1949 defined thika tenant (s.2(5)), grounds for ejectment (s.3), procedure before Controller (s.5(1)); s.28 for pre-Act decrees, s.29 for pending proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.5(1) applies to original applications by landlord to eject on s.3 grounds, not execution of existing decrees.

court_reasoning.text: Ordinance XV/1952 amended definition; s.5(2) allowed judgment-debtor to challenge status within 3 months for decrees in specified period; if no application, decree executable under ordinary law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decree here under s.5(2) Ordinance; appellant did not apply within time.

court_reasoning.text: Amendment Act VI/1953 adopted amendments, omitted ss.28/29, continued s.5(2) proceedings via s.9; deletion of 'subject to s.28' in s.5(1) does not enlarge Controller's jurisdiction to execution of decrees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.5(1) procedure (notice, inquiry on s.3 grounds) inapplicable to decree execution.

court_reasoning.text: Primary rule: interpret words in plain grammatical meaning; only if ambiguous, consider policy/mischief.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.5(1) words clearly apply to fresh ejectment claims, not decrees; s.3 inapplicable to decree-holder enforcing decree.

court_reasoning.text: Legislature revised policy by deleting s.28, limiting protection to timely applications under Ordinance s.5(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No undue strain on words for beneficial construction.

holdings.text: Landlords holding decrees for ejectment against thika tenants not required to apply under s.5(1); civil courts have jurisdiction to entertain execution.

precedents_cited.relevance: Mischief rule for construing welfare statutes: consider mischief, remedy; but primary rule is plain meaning of words.

statutes_cited.name: Calcutta Thika Tenancy Act, 1949 (West Bengal Act II of 1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines thika tenant, ejectment grounds, Controller procedure for fresh claims; ss.28/29 (later omitted) for pre/pending decrees; s.5(1) not for execution.

statutes_cited.name: Calcutta Thika Tenancy Amendment Ordinance, 1952 (West Bengal XV of 1952)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended definition; right to challenge decrees in specified period before court/Controller.

statutes_cited.name: Calcutta Thika Tenancy Amendment Act, 1953 (West Bengal VI of 1953)
statutes_cited.relevance: Adopted amendments; omitted ss.28/29; continued Ordinance s.5(2) proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for appellant's objections in execution.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds civil courts have jurisdiction to entertain execution of ejectment decree against thika tenant under s.5(1) as amended; affirms orders below directing vacation of premises.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; execution to proceed.

key_quotes.text: "a landlord wishing to eject a thika tenant on one or more of the grounds specified in section 3 shall apply in the prescribed manner to the Controller"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.5(1); shows applies to fresh claims, not decree execution.

key_quotes.text: "the first and primary rule of construction is that the intention of the Legislature must be found in the words used by the Legislature itself."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects strained beneficial construction absent ambiguity.

key_quotes.text: "landlords who have obtained decrees of ejectment against their thika tenants cannot be required to apply under the provisions of s. 5(1) of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
